A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write to them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

When I went homesteading they thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My family came west to homestead 3 and 4 Tills.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By Train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On Albert Street Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I homesteaded in 1906.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Now live in the town of Rose Town.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Steam Engineer and Farmer.

I homesteaded in 1906

Now live in the town of Rose Tow

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Steam Engineer and Farmer.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Not very often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Maggie B. Buelow on Sept. 1st, 1910 in Red River.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

No.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

My mother and father, my brother William, and sister Carrie also came.

William homesteaded on North End of 6-30-15, settled 3rd.

Carrie married Mr. Mitchell and also settled in Red River District.

My brother Herbert, born in Sask., also settled on SE4-30-15.

Old deceased but myself.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

My Dad farmed well over in the early days.

The Indians hauled house supplies by the teams in the red river carts, about twelve or nine together, with their supplies on two poles along side the house and only behind with Choctaw sticks on them. Mother made no children come in the house as she was afraid of them. But she soon found out they were quite harmless.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Church was usually held in a farm house some went with oxen. But none had horses to go.

we did very little travelling.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Not very often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Maggie Bell Beaton on Sept. 1st, 1910 in Red Deer.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

No.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My mother and father, my brother William & sister Carrie also came.

William homesteaded on North End of 6-36-05w4 on SE4.

Carrie married Mr. Mitchell and also settled in Red Deer Dist.

My brother Herbert born in Sask., also settled on SE4.

Old deceased but myself.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

My Dad farmed until 1918 in the early days.

The Indians hauled horses regularly by the farmers in the red river carts about twice a week together with their supplies on two poles along side the house and only behind with two oxen on them. Mother made no children come in the house as she was afraid of them. But she soon found out they were quite harmless.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) how often? How far? By what means of travel?

Church was usually held in a farm house some went with oxen. But army had horses to go.

We did very little travelling.

25. When was the first car used in the community? The first car was purchased by Mr. Thomas Westly in 1914.

26. Did you own a car before 1914? No, I did not own a car before 1914.

27. Where was your nearest town? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to travel by horse and buggy or by automobile? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? About 3 or 4 times a year.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Our first phone was installed in 1917 by the Western Electric Co.

33. When you came to Rockford, the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

My Dad came with the intention of staying permanently and didn't also decide to stay.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some homesteaders sold out after proving up and moved to other places.

Some started their business venture to buy other land and etc.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Not many moved from this district.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

I was about 21 years old when I started my first job at the school.

And about 20 years old when I started my second job at the post office.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I had one of the first combines.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of

First Post Office was named Rocktown after an old gentleman who called Pad Rose, who homesteaded there. Postoffice was run by Mr. M. H. Hartley. You see, Postoffice was run about 13 miles from where the town is now.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1912? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some homesteaders moved out after proving up and moved to other places.

Some to start their business, some to buy other land and etc.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930-42? Did many return?

Not many moved from this district.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

I was about 21 years old when I started working at the school.

And about 20 years in the school board.

Small place next to farm.

I had one of the first combines.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible (such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in name since the first name was given; date and reason for change.

Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

First Post Office was named Rocktown after an old gentleman who lived there.

Post Office was run by Mr. M. Heavener.

Mr. Heavener homesteaded about 1 mile from where the town is now.

Railroads, Market Roads, Highways, Telephone, Electricity, Schools, Towns.
